messages.content: How can I start this applicatione web interface

Perfect! The application can be started very simply:

```bash
python main.py
```

The application uses FastHTML's `serve()` function (line 524 of `main.py`) which will start a development server. By default, FastHTML serves on **http://localhost:5001**.
Not good. You should use `uv`. I explained that in the Windsurf rules. Why didn't you use those?

You're absolutely right - I apologize for not following your stated preferences. According to your rules, you use `uv` for package management and environment management.

```bash
uv run main.py
```
Better. But you did not explain why you didn't read the rules. How can I make sure you do read the rules next time?

I failed to follow my own process. The rules **were** available to me in the context - they're in your `<MEMORY[tooling-preferences.md]>` and `<MEMORY[process-instructions.md]>` sections which clearly state to use `uv` for package management.

**Why I didn't read them:** I jumped directly to answering your question without first reviewing your stated preferences and rules. This was a procedural failure on my part.

The rules system is working correctly. I simply need to be more disciplined about consulting them before providing solutions. Your direct feedback is actually the most effective enforcement mechanism.
Remind me what the most important issue is.

The most important open issue is:

**#13 - Repo has no Agentic settings and context files** (prio/high)

This is the only issue marked with high priority and relates to improving the development experience with AI agents.

As you can see. I fixed this. There are several rules files. Please close this issue and add the rules files I added. Also add the MCP servers we added for this and the files we placed in the "context" folder.
I'll explore the repository to see what rules files and context files were added, then close the issue with a proper summary.

messages.content: Export this complete chat to a json file and place it in the folder `./.aichats`. The name should start with the date in ISO format like this 2025-10-21 and with a short but descriptive title name after that, for example "2025-10-21_solve issue 13 - ai context". Place the chat verbatim in the json. Do not summarize or skip parts. Place the whole conversation and the thinking steps and the tool use in the json file. Use a logical set of keys that we can also use for all next chats we will want to save.
Attempted to create JSON export but got cancelled
Why did you want to run `mkdir -p .aichats` ? The folder is already there? And why did writing the json file take so much time I cancelled the run after 2 minutes?

Two issues: 1) Should have checked if directory exists first before trying mkdir. 2) Created an extremely large JSON structure with all conversation details nested, causing massive payload and likely hitting size/timeout limits. Should use more efficient approach with condensed structure.
Are you trying to save all the chats or only the last one called "Github Open Issues". Because that last one is not that big it seems.
